item.title: Firms Feel Pressure as Toll Rises in Bangladesh
item.description: With 281 people dead and the owner of a collapsed building in hiding, pressure was growing on companies that had pledged steps to ensure the safety of Bangladeshi factories.
item.category: Children s Place Retail Stores Inc|PLCE|NASDAQ
item.dc:creator: By JULFIKAR ALI MANIK, STEVEN GREENHOUSE and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Volunteers and rescue workers at the collapsed building on Thursday.

item.title: 36 Killed in Fire at Russian Hospital
item.description: Most of the victims were patients confined in the psychiatric hospital outside Moscow because of their ailments, Russian news agencies reported.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Swiss Quotas Highlight Europe’s Immigration Debate
item.description: Under pressure from a populist campaign, the Swiss government has moved to curb migrant numbers from the European Union. The debate in Switzerland has echoed a growing anti-immigration mood elsewhere in the Continent.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Switzerland's justice minister, Simonetta Sommaruga, acknowledged that the purpose of quotas is to stem political opposition to immigration.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: April 26
item.description: The White House says Syria has used chemical weapons; the U.N. votes for a peacekeeping force in Mali; questions about the Bangladesh factory building collapse; teacher protests in Mexico; and a superb production of “Othello” in London.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: A French soldier in Gao, Mali, this month. France sent troops to Mali in January to push the Islamist militants out of the north.

item.title: India Ink: Messages From Sunil Tripathi’s Family and Brown University on His Death
item.description: The body of the Brown University student, who was briefly misidentified as a suspect in the Boston bombings, found in the waters off of India Point Park near Providence, R.I.
item.dc:creator: By SHIVANI VORA

item.title: 36 Killed in Fire at Russian Psychiatric Hospital
item.description: Most of the victims were patients at a psychiatric hospital outside Moscow who were confined to the building because of their mental ailments.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: François Jacob, Geneticist Who Pointed to How Traits Are Inherited, Dies at 92
item.description: Dr. Jacob was a French war hero whose combat wounds forced him to change his career paths from surgeon to scientist, a pursuit that led to a Nobel Prize in 1965.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY
item.media:description: François Jacob, left, and Jacques Monod in 1971. They helped discover how genes are regulated.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Lawmakers Pass Contentious Secrecy Bill
item.description: South Africa’s Parliament on Thursday passed a much-criticized secrecy bill that will restrict access to information and impose hefty fines and jail terms on reporters who publish information the government classifies as secret.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Cuba: U.S. Bars Raúl Castro’s Daughter From a Forum
item.description: The State Department denied the daughter of President Raúl Castro of Cuba permission to attend a gay rights conference in Philadelphia, where she was to receive an award next week.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Attack on Party Office Kills 5 People
item.description: A bomb exploded in Karachi outside an election office of one of Pakistan’s main political parties on Thursday evening, killing five people in the latest attack ahead of the nation’s May 11 elections.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Russia Told U.S. Bomb Suspect Was Radical Islamist
item.description: Members of Congress, counterterrorism officials and outside experts were divided over whether, and how, the security system failed after a 2011 warning on Tamerlan Tsarnaev.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE, MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT.
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry and several senators leaving a classified intelligence briefing in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Kurdish Rebel Group to Withdraw From Turkey
item.description: The main Kurdish rebel group said it would withdraw all of its forces from Turkey by May 8 to end a 30-year conflict with the Turkish state.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Murat Karayilan, commander of the main rebel group, held a rare news conference on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Citizen Accused of Promoting Post-Election Plot in Venezuela
item.description: A United States citizen was arrested and accused of seeking to provoke violence in Venezuela after the recent presidential election.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Protests by Mexican Teachers Continue to Swell
item.description: Members of the teachers’ union in Guerrero State showed their anger, and in some cases turned violent, over President Enrique Peña Nieto’s plan to overhaul the education system.
item.dc:creator: By KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY
item.media:description: Armed with iron rods and rocks, dozens of masked members of the teachers’ union in Guerrero State attacked the local offices of the four major political parties on Wednesday, smashing windows and overturning furniture.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Guinea: Teenager Killed at Opposition Demonstration
item.description: At least one person was shot dead and several were wounded in clashes between security forces and demonstrators after a protest by tens of thousands of opposition supporters in Guinea’s capital, Conakry.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Two More Tibetans Die in Self-Immolations
item.description: The latest deaths bring the total number of Tibetans who have killed themselves by fire since February 2009 to 118, said Radio Free Asia.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: U.S. Says It Suspects Assad Used Chemical Weapons
item.description: The assessment could test President Obama’s repeated warnings that the use of chemical weapons by President Bashar al-Assad might precipitate American intervention in Syria.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Southern Europe’s Recession Threatens to Spread North
item.description: Germany and other nations in Northern Europe could be caught in the recession of Southern Europe, which would slow the continent’s recovery and hinder growth worldwide.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: An ominous sign in Spain, where the unemployment rate is a staggering 27.2 percent.

item.title: U.N. Security Council Votes to Deploy Peacekeeping Troops in Mali
item.description: Despite fears about getting embroiled in the fight against Islamist extremists, the Security Council on Thursday established a force for Mali, building on a recent military intervention by the French.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: A French soldier in Gao, Mali, this month. France sent troops to Mali in January to push the Islamist militants out of the north.

item.title: Outrage Builds After Collapse in Bangladesh
item.description: With more than 250 people dead, a collapsed building’s owner was in hiding and pressure was building on companies that had pledged steps to ensure the safety of Bangladeshi factories.
item.dc:creator: By JULFIKAR ALI MANIK, STEVEN GREENHOUSE and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Volunteers and rescue workers at the collapsed building on Thursday.

item.title: India Ink: Leaving India for the Ivy League
item.description: Sush Krishnamoorthy, a student at Sardar Patel Vidyalaya in New Delhi, has decided to attend Cornell University this fall because of its financial aid package and computer science program.
item.dc:creator: By SUSH KRISHNAMOORTHY

item.title: Portugal’s Education System Faces Cuts
item.description: A court ruling and continuing budgetary difficulties have left Portugal’s government to reduce spending where it can — including in its education system, already one of the weakest in Europe.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Study in Science Shows Monkeys Pick Up Social Cues
item.description: A study published in Science showed that monkeys conditioned to eat a certain color corn switched to a disliked color when other monkeys were eating it.
item.dc:creator: By PAM BELLUCK
item.media:description: An adult male and several juvenile Vervet monkeys feeding on corn that has been dyed pink.

item.title: At War Blog: Senator Feinstein Urges Transfer of Guantánamo Detainees to Yemen
item.description: Senator Dianne Feinstein, the California Democrat, said it was time to consider lifting a ban on repatriating low-level detainees to Yemen from the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Syria Claims Disruption of Rebel Supply Lines
item.description: The government in Damascus claimed to have overrun a bitterly contested town east of Damascus, but rebels disputed these assertions.
item.category: National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and ALAN COWELL
